title: Slab Serif
content:
Was thinking this was a bad Copperplate reproduction until I saw the S. I have no idea what this is. Could certainly use some assistance.

Thank you very much.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [MHS.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557/http:/typophile.com/files/MHS.jpg) | 127.7 KB |
author: umlautthoni

comments.content:
It looks like a slimmed-down woodtype font, like Blackoak:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/blackoak/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/blackoak/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/blackoak/")

Any more information about the source?

No luck on a positive ID yet....

EDITED:  
Looks like an outdoor sign.  
My guess is that it's not a font as such, but rather sign-maker's lettering.  
The effect could be duplicated with a fairly heavy, monoline, boxy or gas-pipe style wide sans. For example Valfle Extended

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ValfleExtended_MHS_5668.gif)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/suitcase/vafle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/suitcase/vafle/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/suitcase/vafle/")  
I trust a kindly typophile could recommend something that is a better match.  
For the \_M\_ and \_H\_ paste on small Clarendon style serifs.  
As for the the \_S\_ the paste could consist of the serif and terminal treatment from any of several "wild west" wood type designs.  
Good choices include Jeff Levine's Saddle Tramp JNL 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SaddleTrampJNL_S_5551.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/saddle-tramp/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/saddle-tramp/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/saddle-tramp/")  
Equally suitable, Blackoak  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Blackoak_S_6709.gif)
 already suggested by Kevin.  
In both of these cases some tinkering would be needed to get the terminal to match.  
Don

Thank you very much for your input. It is indeed an outdoor banner from Malibu High School. When I did a Google image search, it came up with three different typefaces for MHS. It appears MHS does not employ a graphic standards manual. ;)

As for a base font for \_S\_ FF QType Square Bold is close to the MHS sign

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557im_/http:/typophile.com/files/FFQTypeSquareBold_S_4120.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-qtype/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032557/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-qtype/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-qtype/")  
Don
